messages.content: Lease says 'no aggressive breeds' but doesn't list which breeds. My rescue dog is part pit bull. Am I in violation?
Vague breed restrictions create real uncertainty. It makes sense to ask for clarity when your pet's housing depends on unclear terms.
Should I tell them about the pit bull part? Don't want to get evicted

Understanding breed restrictions:
• Request written list of restricted breeds
• Many 'aggressive breed' lists are outdated
• Focus on your dog's behavior record
• Vet references about temperament help
• Some areas prohibit breed discrimination
• Consider pet liability insurance
• Document training certificates if any

Getting clarity protects both you and your pet. Consider asking for policy details in writing.
Black mold spreading in bathroom. Reported it twice, they just say 'clean it.' Getting headaches. How do I document this properly?
Mold affecting your health while being told to just clean it is concerning. Your instinct to document thoroughly shows you understand this is serious.
What kind of documentation will actually make them act?

Effective mold documentation:
• Photos with dates showing growth progression
• Written timeline of all reports
• Keep copies of all communications
• Document any health symptoms
• Humidity readings if possible
• Request inspection in writing
• Mention 'habitability concerns'
• Consider certified letter for paper trail

Health impacts make this urgent. Local health departments often investigate mold complaints.
Moved in 3 weeks ago, still no mailbox key. Post office says landlord must provide. Missing important mail
Three weeks without mail access is frustrating, especially with important documents potentially waiting. This basic need shouldn't take so long.
What's the normal process for getting a mailbox key?

Mailbox key process:
• Landlords typically provide at move-in
• USPS requires owner authorization for new keys
• Document your requests with dates
• Mention missing important mail
• Request temporary mail hold at post office
• Some tenants use certified mail to create urgency
• 3 weeks is unusually long

Consider putting request in writing noting the delay's impact.
Got renewal offer with new rules about guests and parking. Can they add restrictions I never agreed to before?
Unexpected new restrictions at renewal time feels like changing the rules mid-game. It's natural to question whether this is standard practice.
Do I have to accept these new terms or can I keep the old ones?

Lease renewal options:
• Renewals can include new terms
• You can negotiate changes
• Request explanation for new restrictions
• Compare to original lease
• Month-to-month may maintain old terms
• Consider proposing compromise
• Get any agreements in writing
• Local tenant orgs know your rights

You're not obligated to accept - it's a new contract negotiation.
They switched to online-only rent payment with $15 'convenience fee.' No other options. This adds $180/year to my rent!
Forced fees for paying rent feels like a hidden rent increase. Your frustration about $180 in extra annual costs is completely understandable.
Is it legal to force us to pay fees just to pay rent?

Payment fee considerations:
• Some states regulate payment fees
• Check if lease addresses payment methods
• Document the fee requirement
• Ask about fee-free options in writing
• Some systems offer ACH without fees
• Tenant groups often challenge these fees
• Calculate total annual impact

Consider requesting a fee-free payment option. Local tenant resources can clarify your area's rules.

Dishwasher leaking slowly for a month. Worried about floor damage. How urgent is this?
Maintenance delays affect quality of life. It's reasonable to want clear timelines for repairs.
What's a reasonable timeframe for this repair?

Typical repair timelines:
• Emergency (no water/heat/safety): 24-72 hours
• Urgent (affecting daily life): 3-7 days  
• Routine (minor issues): 14-30 days
• Document all requests with dates
• Follow up in writing if no response
• Take photos of the issue
• Keep records of impact on you

Consider escalating if timelines aren't met.

Understanding charges and fees:
